title: Lars-Erik Torph
text:
Lars-Erik Torph (11 January 1961 – 23 January 1989) was a <a href="Sweden">Swedish</a> <a href="Rallying">rally</a> driver. He debuted in the <a href="World%20Rally%20Championship">World Rally Championship</a> in 1980 and took his first points at his home event, the <a href="Swedish%20Rally">Swedish Rally</a>, in 1984. Driving a <a href="Toyota%20Celica">Toyota Celica TCT</a>, a <a href="Toyota%20Supra">Toyota Supra 3.0i</a> and an <a href="Audi%20Coup%C3%A9%20Quattro">Audi Coupé Quattro</a>, he went on to finish on the podium four times. After just turning 28, Torph and his co-driver <a href="Bertil-Rune%20Rehnfeldt">Bertil-Rune Rehnfeldt</a> died while spectating the 1989 <a href="Monte%20Carlo%20Rally">Monte Carlo Rally</a>, after <a href="Lancia">Lancia</a> driver <a href="Alex%20Fiorio">Alex Fiorio</a> lost control of his <a href="Lancia%20Delta%20Integrale">Delta Integrale</a> and crashed into them.
Career.
Torph debuted in the World Rally Championship during the <a href="1980%20World%20Rally%20Championship%20season">1980 season</a>, competing with a <a href="Volvo%20142">Volvo 142</a> at the <a href="Swedish%20Rally">Swedish Rally</a> and at the <a href="1000%20Lakes%20Rally">1000 Lakes Rally</a> in Finland, retiring in both events. At his seventh WRC event, the 1984 Swedish Rally, he took his first WRC points by finishing fifth in an <a href="Opel%20Ascona">Opel Ascona</a> for the Opel Team Sweden. In <a href="1985%20World%20Rally%20Championship%20season">1985</a>, Torph drove to 11th place at his home event and then placed in the points at the 1000 Lakes Rally, taking ninth place in a <a href="Volkswagen%20Golf%20GTI">Volkswagen Golf GTI</a> for the Swedish Junior Team.
In the <a href="1986%20World%20Rally%20Championship%20season">1986 season</a>, Torph competed in three rallies for <a href="Toyota%20Team%20Europe">Toyota Team Europe</a>, <a href="Toyota">Toyota</a>'s factory WRC team. He took his <a href="Toyota%20Celica">Toyota Celica TCT</a> to second place at the endurance events <a href="Safari%20Rally">Safari Rally</a> and <a href="Rallye%20C%C3%B4te%20d%27Ivoire">Rallye Côte d'Ivoire</a>, losing the wins to compatriot and teammate <a href="Bj%C3%B6rn%20Waldeg%C3%A5rd">Björn Waldegård</a>. At the <a href="Olympus%20Rally">Olympus Rally</a>, Torph finished fourth, but this time ahead of Waldegård who took fifth place. Points from these events placed Torph sixth in drivers' world championship.
In <a href="1987%20World%20Rally%20Championship%20season">1987</a>, Torph again had a three-event contract with Toyota. He started his season at the Swedish Rally and finished 11th in his privateer <a href="Audi%2080%20Quattro">Audi 80 Quattro</a>. With a factory <a href="Toyota%20Supra">Toyota Supra 3.0i</a>, he finished third at the Safari Rally behind <a href="Audi%20Sport">Audi Sport</a>'s <a href="Hannu%20Mikkola">Hannu Mikkola</a> and <a href="Walter%20R%C3%B6hrl">Walter Röhrl</a>, despite a <a href="fever">fever</a> that lasted almost the duration of the event. At the Olympus Rally, he retired due to an engine problem. On the second day of the Rallye Côte d'Ivoire, Toyota's <a href="Cessna%20340">Cessna 340</a> aircraft crashed down and exploded, killing manager <a href="Henry%20Liddon%20%28driver%29">Henry Liddon</a>, his assistant Nigel Harris, the pilot and the navigator. Toyota boss <a href="Ove%20Andersson">Ove Andersson</a> withdrew all the factory Supra Turbos from the event.
During the <a href="1988%20World%20Rally%20Championship%20season">1988 season</a>, Torph participated in only two WRC events. In Sweden, driving a privateer <a href="Audi%20Coup%C3%A9%20Quattro">Audi Coupé Quattro</a>, he took his fourth podium place finishing behind <a href="Markku%20Al%C3%A9n">Markku Alén</a> and <a href="Stig%20Blomqvist">Stig Blomqvist</a>. For the Safari Rally, Torph had a factory team contract with <a href="Volkswagen">Volkswagen</a> but retired after his Golf GTI 16V developed an engine problem. Torph continued with the Coupé Quattro for the Team <a href="Volkswagen%20Group">VAG</a> Sweden in the <a href="1989%20World%20Rally%20Championship%20season">1989 season</a> opener in Sweden, but retired after an ignition problem.
Death.
At the 1989 <a href="Monte%20Carlo%20Rally">Monte Carlo Rally</a>, Torph was not competing but only doing the <a href="Reconnaissance%20%28rallying%29">reconnaissance</a> ("recce") to help fellow Swedish rally driver Fredrik Skoghag regarding <a href="pacenotes">pacenotes</a> on icy surface. While taking a break from recce duties, Torph and his co-driver Bertil-Rune Rehnfeldt went to spectate the fifth stage of the rally. Italian driver <a href="Alex%20Fiorio">Alex Fiorio</a> lost control of his <a href="Lancia%20Delta%20Integrale">Lancia Delta Integrale</a>, and then regained it only to go off the road and down an embankment on the other side. At about 145 km/h (90 mph), the car crashed into Torph and Rehnfeldt, killing both. Fiorio and his co-driver Luigi Pirollo were unhurt. Witnesses said that hitting a bump had caused Fiorio to lose control of his car. Skoghag withdrew from the event, and <a href="Lancia">Lancia</a>'s factory team <a href="Martini%20Racing">Martini Lancia</a> locked out the podium with drivers <a href="Miki%20Biasion">Miki Biasion</a> 1st, <a href="Didier%20Auriol">Didier Auriol</a> 2nd and <a href="Bruno%20Saby">Bruno Saby</a> 3rd.
